ANU.name: Jessie Moritz
ANU.colleges: College of Arts and Social Sciences
interest: Middle East political economy, comparative politics, state-society relations, Gulf security and international relations, energy politics, political economy of development. Particular country interests in Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Bahrain, Oman, Kuwait, UAE, Iraq, Jordan, and Libya.

publication.title: Re-conceptualizing civil society in rentier states
publication.source: British Journal of Middle Eastern Studies, vol. 47, no. 1, pp. 136-151

publication.title: Rentier Political Economy in the oil monarchies
publication.source: in Mehran Kamrava (ed.), Routledge Handbook of of Persian Gulf Politics, Routledge Taylor and Francis Group, UK, pp. pp 163-186

publication.title: Oil and societal quiescence: Rethinking causal mechanisms in rentier state theory
publication.source: in   (ed.), The Politics of Rentier States in the Gulf, The Project on Middle East Political Science,, Washington, pp. 40-43

publication.title: Reformers and the Rentier State: Re-Evaluating the Co-Optation Mechanism in Rentier State Theory
publication.source: Journal of Arabian Studies, vol. 8, no. 1, pp. 46-64pp

publication.title: The Easy Enemy: The Shia and Sectarianism in the Arab States of the Gulf and Yemen during the Arab Spring
publication.source: in K. Scott Parker & Tony E. Nasrallah (ed.), Middle Eastern Minorities and the Arab Spring: Identity and Community in the Twenty-First Century, Gorgias Press LLC, Piscataway, New Jersey, pp. 227-258

publication.title: Rents, Start-ups, and Obstacles to SME Entrepreneuralism in Oman, Bahrain and Qatar
publication.source: in Annika Kropf and Mohamed Ramady  (ed.), Employment and Career Motivation In The Arab Gulf States: The Rentier Mentality Revisited, Gerlach Press, Berlin, pp. 201-222

publication.title: The Contemporary Middle East: Revolution or reform?
publication.source: Melbourne University Press (an imprint of Melbourne University Publishing)Carlton, Vic

publication.title: Understanding and Interpreting Change in the Middle East and North Africa
publication.source: in Adel Abdel Ghafar, Brenton Clark and Jessie Moritz (ed.), The Contemporary Middle East: Revolution or Reform?, Melbourne University Press (an imprint of Melbourne University Publishing), Carlton, Vic, pp. 1-17
